paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade therapy in tumors?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse combination therapy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy across multiple repeat experiments

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice receiving vaccine only, ICI only, or vehicle control treatments across matched control groups

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic cancer patients receiving ICI treatment with documented vaccination status

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the metastatic cohort who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before or during ICI treatment

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the metastatic cohort who did not receive SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination prior to ICI treatment

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, introducing potential residual confounding factors that limit causal inference
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, potentially affecting treatment outcomes and consistency
Heterogeneous mix of tumor types and treatment histories across the patient cohort complicates direct interpretation of results
Mouse model findings may not translate directly to all human tumor types and clinical settings
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than being uniformly consistent across all tested experimental settings
